p.s: The relationship between Weimar and Shakespeare - his work's true way into Germany
Did you know that the Deutsche Shakespeare Gesellschaft held its spring conference in Bochum, which is the, historically seen, wrong city to celebrate its 150th anniversary?
I certainly did not know, which is why I read the article Wie Shakespeares Denkmal in den Weimarer Ilmpark kam, published on 24. April 2016 by Th√ºringer Allgemeine and written by Wolfgang Hirsch.
In this article, Hirsch describes how Shakespeare's work found its way to Germany, as well as the relationship between Weimar and Shakespeare.
Because I am taking part in the international school project Global Shakespeare, I think it is very interesting to share the information which is given in the article.
Hirsch starts off his article by talking about how greatly celebratetcelebrated Shakespeare is in the United Kingdom and how many tourists come to visit his hometown Stratford-upon-Avon, UK.
Here, the question arises how Shakespeare's work found its way into Germany.
As alredyalready mentioned above, in 2016 the German Shakespeare committee held its spring conference in Bochum, which is, historically seen, the wrong city to celebrate him.
Why you may ask?
Hirsch describes how no one in Germany knew about Shakespeare until the late 18th century, due to missing translations.
In the Ilm Arkadien his way through German literature began.
Christoph Martin Wieland, the founding father of German classic, was first to translate Shakespeare's work into the German language.
Between 1762 and 1766, Wieland has published 22 of Shakespeare's plays.
However, the Jenaer professor for German studies Klaus Manger, explains that Goethe and Herder also knew a little bit about Shakespeare and represent parts of his work in their own work.
Wieland, Goethe and Herder, the leaders of the German Shakespeare Renaissance, all found themselves in Weimar.
Manger explains that other famous poets and other men well known in literature have translated Shakespeare's work and even managed to write modern translations.
Yet no one was able to translate please like Sommernachtstraum as magically as Wieland did, Manger claims.
On 8. April 1864, the Verein der Shakespeare-Freunde was founded in Weimar.
Hirsch states that it must have been extremely inspiring, because it is the oldest literature society in Germany.
For the 40th anniversary of the commiteecommittee and Shakespeare's 340th birthday, a memorial with all the appropriate attributes, made by Otto Lessing was build forhim.
On 23rd April 1904 is was initiated.
Today, the memorial is part of the Unesco-Weltkulturerbe, and has been since 1998.
Concluding, Shakespeare found his way into German literature through Christoph Martin Wieland and his highly celebrated, throughout Germany.
He is especially honored in Weimar.
